column1: Hark the gossip of the grasses       Bivouacked beneath the moon!
column2: Hark the leaves their mirth averring;       Hark the buds to blossom stirring;         Hark the hushed, exultant haste       Of the wind and world conferring!
column3: Hark the sharp, insistent cry       Where the hawk patrols the sky!
column4: Hark the flapping, as of banners,       Where the heron triumphs by!
column5: Empire in the coasts of bloom       Humming cohorts now resume,--         And desire is forth to follow       Many a vagabond perfume.
column6: Long the quest and far the ending       Where my wayfarer is wending,--         When desire is once afoot,       Doom behind and dream attending!
column7: Shuttle-cock of indecision,       Sport of chance’s blind derision,         Yet he may not fail nor tire       Till his eyes shall win the Vision.
column8: In his ears the phantom chime       Of incommunicable rhyme,         He shall chase the fleeting camp-fires       Of the Bedouins of Time.
column9: Farer by uncharted ways,       Dumb as Death to plaint or praise,         Unreturning he shall journey,       Fellow to the nights and days:--       Till upon the outer bar       Stilled the moaning currents are,--         Till the flame achieves the zenith,--       Till the moth attains the star,--       Till, through laughter and through tears,       Fair the final peace appears,         And about the watered pastures       Sink to sleep the nomad years!
column10: Where the Cattle come to Drink       At evening, where the cattle come to drink,         Cool are the long marsh-grasses, dewy cool         The alder thickets, and the shallow pool,       And the brown clay about the trodden brink.
column11: The pensive afterthoughts of sundown sink         Over the patient acres given to peace;         The homely cries and farmstead noises cease,       And the worn day relaxes, link by link.
column12: A lesson that the open heart may read         Breathes in this mild benignity of air,         These dear, familiar savours of the soil,--       A lesson of the calm of humble creed,         The simple dignity of common toil,         And the plain wisdom of unspoken prayer.
column13: The Heal-All       Dear blossom of the wayside kin,         Whose homely, wholesome name       Tells of a potency within         To win thee country fame!
column14: The sterile hillocks are thy home,         Beside the windy path;       The sky, a pale and lonely dome,         Is all thy vision hath.
column15: Thy unobtrusive purple face         Amid the meagre grass       Greets me with long-remembered grace,         And cheers me as I pass.
column16: And I, outworn by petty care,         And vexed with trivial wrong,       I heed thy brave and joyous air         Until my heart grows strong.
column17: A lesson from the Power I crave         That moves in me and thee,       That makes thee modest, calm, and brave,--         Me restless as the sea.
column18: Thy simple wisdom I would gain,--         To heal the hurt Life brings,       With kindly cheer, and faith in pain,         And joy of common things.
column19: Recompense       To Beauty and to Truth I heaped         My sacrificial fires.
column20: I fed them hot with selfish thoughts         And many proud desires.
column21: I stripped my days of dear delights         To cast them in the flame,       Till life seemed naked as a rock,         And pleasure but a name.
column22: And still I sorrowed patiently,         And waited day and night,       Expecting Truth from very far         And Beauty from her height.
column23: Then laughter ran among the stars;         And this I heard them tell:       “Beside his threshold is the shrine         Where Truth and Beauty dwell!”             An Epitaph for a Husbandman       He who would start and rise         Before the crowing cocks--       No more he lifts his eyes,         Whoever knocks.
column24: He who before the stars         Would call the cattle home,--       They wait about the bars         For him to come.
column25: Him at whose hearty calls         The farmstead woke again       The horses in their stalls         Expect in vain.
column26: Busy, and blithe, and bold,         He laboured for the morrow,--       The plough his hands would hold         Rusts in the furrow.
column27: His fields he had to leave,         His orchards cool and dim;       The clods he used to cleave         Now cover him.
column28: But the green, growing things         Lean kindly to his sleep,--       White roots and wandering strings,         Closer they creep.
column29: Because he loved them long         And with them bore his part,       Tenderly now they throng         About his heart.
column30: The Little Field of Peace       By the long wash of his ancestral sea         He sleeps how quietly!
column31: How quiet the unlifting eyelids lie         Under this tranquil sky!
column32: The little busy hands and restless feet         Here find that rest is sweet;       For sweetly, from the hands grown tired of play,         The child-world slips away,       With its confusion of forgotten toys         And kind, familiar noise.
column33: Not lonely does he lie in his last bed,         For love o’erbroods his head.
column34: Kindly to him the comrade grasses lean         Their fellowship of green.
column35: The wilding meadow companies give heed,--         Brave tansy, and the weed       That on the dyke-top lifts its dauntless stalk,--         Around his couch they talk.
column36: The shadows of his oak-tree flit and play         Above his dreams all day.
column37: The wind, that was his playmate on the hills,         His sleep with music fills.
column38: Here in this tender acre by the tide         His vanished kin abide.
column40: what compassionate care for him they keep,         Too soon returned to sleep!
column41: They watch him in this little field of peace         Where they have found release.
column42: Not as a stranger or alone he went         Unto his long content;       But kissed to sleep and comforted lies he         By his ancestral sea.
column43: Renewal       Comrade of the whirling planets,         Mother of the leaves and rain,       Make me joyous as thy birds are,         Let me be thy child again.
column44: Show me all the troops of heaven         Tethered in a sphere of dew,--       All the dear familiar marvels         Old, child-hearted singers knew.
column45: Let me laugh with children’s laughter,         Breathe with herb and blade and tree,       Learn again forgotten lessons         Of thy grave simplicity.
column46: Take me back to dream and vision         From the prison-house of pain,       Back to fellowship with wonder--         Mother, take me home again!
column47: The Unsleeping       I soothe to unimagined sleep       The sunless bases of the deep.
column48: And then I stir the aching tide       That gropes in its reluctant side.
column49: I heave aloft the smoking hill;       To silent peace its throes I still.
column50: But ever at its heart of fire       I lurk, an unassuaged desire.
column51: I wrap me in the sightless germ       An instant or an endless term;       And still its atoms are my care,       Dispersed in ashes or in air.
column52: I hush the comets one by one       To sleep for ages in the sun;       The sun resumes before my face       His circuit of the shores of space.
column53: The mount, the star, the germ, the deep,       They all shall wake, they all shall sleep.
column54: Time, like a flurry of wild rain,       Shall drift across the darkened pane.
column55: Space, in the dim predestined hour,       Shall crumble like a ruined tower.
column56: I only, with unfaltering eye,       Shall watch the dreams of God go by.
column57: Recessional       Now along the solemn heights       Fade the Autumn’s altar-lights;           Down the great earth’s glimmering chancel       Glide the days and nights.
column58: Little kindred of the grass,       Like a shadow in a glass           Falls the dark and falls the stillness;       We must rise and pass.
column59: We must rise and follow, wending       Where the nights and days have ending,--           Pass in order pale and slow       Unto sleep extending.
column60: Little brothers of the clod,       Soul of fire and seed of sod,           We must fare into the silence       At the knees of God.
column61: Little comrades of the sky       Wing to wing we wander by,           Going, going, going, going,       Softly as a sigh.
column62: Hark, the moving shapes confer,       Globe of dew and gossamer,           Fading and ephemeral spirits       In the dusk astir.
column63: Moth and blossom, blade and bee,       Worlds must go as well as we,           In the long procession joining       Mount, and star, and sea.
column64: Toward the shadowy brink we climb       Where the round year rolls sublime,           Rolls, and drops, and falls forever       In the vast of time;       Like a plummet plunging deep       Past the utmost reach of sleep,           Till remembrance has no longer       Care to laugh or weep.
column65: Earth’s Complines       Before the feet of the dew       There came a call I knew,           Luring me into the garden       Where the tall white lilies grew.
column66: I stood in the dusk between       The companies of green,           O’er whose aerial ranks       The lilies rose serene.
column67: And the breathing air was stirred       By an unremembered word,           Soft, incommunicable--       And wings not of a bird.
column68: I heard the spent blooms sighing,       The expectant buds replying;           I felt the life of the leaves,       Ephemeral, yet undying.
column69: The spirits of earth were there,       Thronging the shadowed air,           Serving among the lilies,       In an ecstasy of prayer.
column70: Their speech I could not tell;       But the sap in each green cell,           And the pure initiate petals,       They knew that language well.
column71: I felt the soul of the trees--       Of the white, eternal seas--           Of the flickering bats and night-moths       And my own soul kin to these.
column72: And a spell came out of space       From the light of its starry place,           And I saw in the deep of my heart       The image of God’s face.
column73: Two Spheres       While eager angels watched in awe,         God fashioned with his hands       Two shining spheres to work his law,         And carry his commands.
column74: With patient art he shaped them true,         With calm, untiring care;       And none of those bright watchers knew         Which one to call most fair.
column75: He dropped one lightly down to earth         Amid the morning’s blue--       And on a gossamer had birth         A bead of blinding dew.
column76: It flamed across the hollow field,         On tiptoe to depart,       Outvied Arcturus, and revealed         All heaven in its heart.
column77: He tossed the other into space         (As children toss a ball)       To swing forever in its place         With equal rise and fall;       To flame through the ethereal dark,         Among its brother spheres,       An orbit too immense to mark         The little tide of years.
column78: The Stillness of the Frost       Out of the frost-white wood comes winnowing through         No wing; no homely call or cry is heard.

column80: The hard hills ache beneath their spectral hue.
column81: A dove-gray cloud, tender as tears or dew,         From one lone hearth exhaling, hangs unstirred,         Like the poised ghost of some unnamed great bird         In the ineffable pallor of the blue.
column82: Such, I must think, even at the dawn of Time,         Was thy white hush, O world, when thou lay’st cold,         Unwaked to love, new from the Maker’s word,       And the spheres, watching, stilled their high accord,         To marvel at perfection in thy mould,         The grace of thine austerity sublime!
column83: A Child’s Prayer at Evening         (_Domine, cui sunt Pleiades curae_)       Father, who keepest         The stars in Thy care,       Me, too, Thy little one,         Childish in prayer,       Keep, as Thou keepest         The soft night through,       Thy long, white lilies         Asleep in Thy dew.

column91: Beside the Winter Sea       As one who sleeps, and hears across his dream       The cry of battles ended long ago,       Inland I hear the calling of the sea.
column92: I hear its hollow voices, though between       My wind-worn dwelling and thy wave-worn strand       How many miles, how many mountains are!
column93: And thou beside the winter sea alone       Art walking, with thy cloak about thy face.
column94: Bleak, bleak the tide, and evening coming on;       And gray the pale, pale light that wans thy face.
column95: Solemnly breaks the long wave at thy feet;       And sullenly in patches clings the snow       Upon the low, red rocks worn round with years.
column96: I see thine eyes, I see their grave desire,       Unsatisfied and lonely as the sea’s;--       Yet how unlike the wintry sea’s despair!
column97: For could my feet but follow, thine, my hands       But reach for thy warm hands beneath thy cloak,       What summer joy would lighten in thy face,       What sunshine warm thine eyes, and thy sad mouth       Break to a dewy rose, and laugh on mine!
column98: The Quest of the Arbutus       For days the drench of noiseless rains,       Then sunshine on the vacant plains,       And April with her blind desire       A vagrant in my veins!
column99: Because the tardy gods grew kind,       Unrest and care were cast behind;       I took a day, and found the world       Was fashioned to my mind.
column100: The swelling sap that thrilled the wood       Was cousin to my eager blood;       I caught the stir of waking roots,       And knew that life was good.
column101: But something in the odors fleet,       And in the sap’s suggestion sweet,       Was lacking,--one thing everywhere       To make the spring complete.
column102: At length within a leafy nest,       Where spring’s persuasions pleaded best,       I found a pale, reluctant flower,       The purpose of my quest.
column103: And then the world’s expectancy       Grew clear: I knew its need to be       Not this dear flower, but one dear hand       To pluck the flower with me.
column104: The Jonquil       Through its brown and withered bulb         How the white germ felt the sun       In the dark mould gently stirring         His Spring children one by one!
column105: Thrilled with heat, it split the husk,         Shot a green blade up to light,       And unfurled its orange petals         In the old Enchanter’s sight.
column106: One step more and it had floated         On the palpitating noon       Winged and free, a butterfly         Soaring from the rent cocoon.
column107: But it could not leave its earth,         And the May-dew’s tender tears,--       So it wavers there forever         ’Twixt the green and azure spheres.
column108: The Trout Brook       The airs that blew from the brink of day       Were fresh and wet with the breath of May.
column109: I heard the babble of brown brooks falling,       And golden-wings in the woodside calling.
column110: Big drops hung from the sparkling eaves;       And through the screen of the thin young leaves       A glint of ripples, a whirl of foam,       Lured and beckoned me out from home.
column111: My feet grew eager, my eyes grew wide,       And I was off by the brown brook’s side.
column112: Down in the swamp-bottom, cool and dim,       I cut me an alder sapling slim.
column113: With nimble fingers I tied my line,       Clear as a sunbeam, strong and fine.
column114: My fly was a tiny glittering thing,       With tinselled body and partridge wing.
column115: With noiseless steps I threaded the wood,       Glad of the sun-pierced solitude.
column116: Chattered the kingfisher, fierce and shy,       As like a shadow I drifted by.
column117: Lurked in their watery lairs the trout,       But, silver and scarlet, I lured them out.
column118: Wary were they, but warier still       My cunning wrist and my cast of skill.
column119: I whipped the red pools under the beeches;       I whipped the yellow and dancing reaches.
column120: The purple eddy, smooth like oil,       And the tail of the rapid yielded spoil.
column121: So all day long, till the day was done,       I followed the stream, I followed the sun.
column122: Then homeward over the ridge I went,       The wandering heart of me well content.

column136: Butterflies       Once in a garden, when the thrush’s song,         Pealing at morn, made holy all the air,       Till earth was healed of many an ancient wrong,         And life appeared another name for prayer,       Rose suddenly a swarm of butterflies,         On wings of white and gold and azure fire;       And one said, “These are flowers that seek the skies,         Loosed by the spell of their supreme desire.”             July       I am for the open meadows,         Open meadows full of sun,       Where the hot bee hugs the clover,         The hot breezes drop and run.
column137: I am for the uncut hayfields         Open to the cloudless blue,--       For the wide unshadowed acres         Where the summer’s pomps renew;       Where the grass-tops gather purple,         Where the ox-eye daisies thrive,       And the mendicants of summer         Laugh to feel themselves alive;       Where the hot scent steams and quivers,         Where the hot saps thrill and stir,       Where in leaf-cells’ green pavilions         Quaint artificers confer;       Where the bobolinks are merry,         Where the beetles bask and gleam,       Where above the powdered blossoms         Powdered moth-wings poise and dream;       Where the bead-eyed mice adventure         In the grass-roots green and dun.
column138: Life is good and love is eager         In the playground of the sun!
column139: An August Wood Road       When the partridge coveys fly       In the birch-tops cool and high;       When the dry cicadas twang       Where the purpling fir-cones hang;       When the bunch-berries emboss--       Scarlet beads--the roadside moss:       Brown with shadows, bright with sun,       All day long till day is done       Sleeps in murmuring solitude       The worn old road that threads the wood.
column140: In its deep cup--grassy, cool--       Sleeps the little roadside pool;       Sleeps the butterfly on the weed,       Sleeps the drifted thistle-seed.
column141: Like a great and blazing gem,       Basks the beetle on the stem.
column142: Up and down the shining rays       Dancing midges weave their maze.
column143: High among the moveless boughs,       Drunk with day, the night-hawks drowse.
column144: Far up, unfathomably blue,       August’s heaven vibrates through.
column145: The old road leads to all things good;       The year’s at full, and time’s at flood.

column159: To scurry in the grass         And to have one’s fling!
column160: And it’s oh, to be a cricket       In the warm thistle-thicket,         Where the sun-winds pass,         Winds a-wing,       And the bumble-bees hang humming,         Hum and swing,       And the honey-drops are coming!
column161: It’s to be a summer rover,         That can see a sweet, and pick it         With the sting!
column163: And it’s oh, to be a cricket         In the clover!

column165: The Train among the Hills       Vast, unrevealed, in silence and the night         Brooding, the ancient hills commune with sleep.

column205: Love’s Translator       When the white moon divides the mist,         My longing eyes believe       ’Tis the white arm my lips have kissed         Flashing from thy sleeve.
column206: And when the tall white lily sways         Upon her queenly stalk,       Thy white form fills my dreaming gaze         Down the garden walk.
column207: When, rich with rose, a wandering air         Breathes up the leafy place,       It seems to me thy perfumed hair         Blown across my face.
column208: And when the thrush’s golden note         Across the gloom is heard,       I think ’tis thy impassioned throat         Uttering one sweet word.
column209: And when the scarlet poppy-bud         Breaks, breathing of the south,       A sudden warmth awakes my blood         Thinking of thy mouth.
column210: And when that dove’s wing dips in flight         Above the dreaming land,       I see some dear, remembered, white         Gesture of thy hand.
column211: Wonder and love upon me wait         In service fair, when I       Into thy sweetness thus translate         Earth and air and sky.

column244: He shuts up the earth, and he opens the skies.
column246: He smiles through his fingers, and shuts up the sun;             (Oh, weary, my Dearie, so weary!)
column247: The stars that he loves he lets out one by one.
column249: He comes from the castles of Drowsy-boy Town;             (Oh, weary, my Dearie, so weary!)
column250: At the touch of his hand the tired eyelids fall down.
column252: He comes with a murmur of dream in his wings             (Oh, weary, my Dearie, so weary!)
column253: And whispers of mermaids and wonderful things.
column255: Then the top is a burden, the bugle a bane             (Oh, weary, my Dearie, so weary!)
column256: When one would be faring down Dream-a-way Lane,             (So hush-a-by, weary my Dearie!)
column257: When one would be wending in Lullaby Wherry             (Oh, weary, my Dearie, so weary!)
column258: To Sleepy Man’s Castle by Comforting Ferry.
column260: III Ballads             The Wrestler       When God sends out His company to travel through the stars,       There is every kind of wonder in the show;       There is every kind of animal behind its prison bars;       With riders in a many-colored row.
column261: The master showman, Time, has a strange trick of rhyme,       And the clown’s most ribald jest is a tear;       But the best drawing card is the Wrestler huge and hard,       Who can fill the tent at any time of year.
column262: His eye is on the crowd, and he beckons with his hand,       With authoritative finger, and they come.
column263: The rules of the game they do not understand,       But they go as in a dream, and are dumb.
column264: They would fain say him nay, and they look the other way,       Till at last to the ropes they cling.
column265: But he throws them one by one till the show for them is done,       In the blood-red dust of the ring.
column266: There’s none to shun his challenge--they must meet him soon or late,       And he knows a cunning trick for all heels.
column267: The king’s haughty crown drops in jeers from his pate       As the hold closes on him, and he reels.
column268: The burly and the proud, the braggarts of the crowd,       Every one of them he topples down in thunder.
column269: His grip grows mild for the dotard and the child,       But alike they must all go under.
column270: Oh, many a mighty foeman would try a fall with him--       Persepolis and Babylon and Rome,       Assyria and Sardis, they see their fame grow dim,       As he tumbles in the dust every dome.
column271: At length will come an hour when the stars shall feel his power,       And he shall have his will upon the sun.
column272: Ere we know what he’s about, the stars will be put out,       And the wonder of the show will be undone.
column273: The Ballad of Crossing the Brook       Oh, it was a dainty maid that went a-Maying in the morn,         A dainty, dainty maiden of degree.
column274: The ways she took were merry and the ways she missed forlorn,         And the laughing water tinkled to the sea.
column275: The little leaves above her loved the dainty, dainty maid;         The little winds they kissed her, every one;       At the nearing of her little feet the flowers were not afraid;         And the water lay a-whimpling in the sun.
column276: Oh, the dainty, dainty maid to the borders of the brook         Lingered down as lightly as the breeze;       And the shy water-spiders quit their scurrying to look;         And the happy water whispered to the trees.
column277: She was fain to cross the brook, was the dainty, dainty maid;         But first she lifted up her elfin eyes       To see if there were cavalier or clown a-near to aid,--         And the water-bubbles blinked in surprise.
column278: The brook bared its pebbles to persuade her dainty feet,         But the dainty, dainty maid was not content.
column279: She had spied a simple country lad (for dainty maid unmeet),         And the shy water twinkled as it went.
column280: As the simple lad drew nigh, then this dainty, dainty maid,         (O maidens, well you know how it was done!)
column281: Stood a-gazing at her feet until he saw she was afraid         Of the water there a-whimpling in the sun.
column282: Now that simple lad had in him all the makings of a man;         And he stammered, “I had better lift you over!”       Said the dainty, dainty maid--“Do you really think you can?”         And the water hid its laughter in the clover.
column283: So he carried her across, with his eyes cast down,         And his foolish heart a-quaking with delight.
column284: And the maid she looked him over with her elfin eyes of brown;         And the impish water giggled at his plight.
column285: He reached the other side, he set down the dainty maid;         But he trembled so he couldn’t speak a word.
column286: Then the dainty, dainty maid--“Thank you, Sir!
column288: And the water-bubbles chuckled as they heard.
column289: Oh, she tripped away so lightly, a-Maying in the morn,         That dainty, dainty maiden of degree;       She left the simple country lad a-sighing and forlorn         Where the mocking water twinkled to the sea.
column290: Whitewaters       Beside the wharf at Whitewaters       The loitering ebb with noon confers;       And o’er the amber flats there seems       A sleep to brood of sun and dreams.
column291: The white and clustering cottages,       Thick shadowed by their windless trees,       Inhabit such a calm, that change       Goes by and lets her face grow strange.
column292: And not far off, on tiptoe seen,       The brown dike and the sky between,       A shifting field that heaves and slides,--       The blue breast of the Minas tides.
column293: A-through the little harbor go       The currents of the scant Pereau,       Drawn slowly, drawn from springs unseen       Amid the marsh’s vasts of green.
column294: Up from the wharf at Whitewaters,       Where scarce a slim sandpiper stirs,       A yellow roadway climbs, that feels       Few footsteps and infrequent wheels.
column295: It climbs to meet the westering sun       Upon the heights of Blomidon,--       Bulwark of peace, whose bastioned form       Out-bars the serried hosts of storm.
column296: *       *       *       *       *       Down to the wharf at Whitewaters,       The children of the villagers       One drowsy, windless hour of noon       Deep in the green mid-heart of June,       Like swallows to a sunset pool       Came chattering, just let loose from school;       And with them one small lad of four,       Picked up as they flocked past his door.
column297: His sea-blue, merry eyes, his hair       Curling and like the corn-silk fair,       His red, sweet mouth, made Hally Clive       Comely as any lad alive.
column298: His father, master of “The Foam,”       Drave his tight craft afar from home;       His mother--peaceful life was hers       With Hally, safe in Whitewaters.
column299: And in his sun-brown arms the boy       Carried his last, most cherished toy;       A small white kitten, free from fleck,       With a blue ribbon round its neck.
column300: In the old timbers lapping cool,       About the wharf the tide hung full;       And at the wharf-side, just afloat,       Swung lazily an old gray boat.
column301: About the froth-white water’s edge,       The weedy planks, the washing sedge,       And in and out the rocking craft,       The children clambered, splashed, and laughed,       Till presently, grown tired of play,       Up the bright road they raced away;       But in the boat, a drowsy heap,       Curled boy and kitten, sound asleep.
column302: Warm in the sunny boat they slept.
column303: Soon to its ebb the slow tide crept.
column304: By stealthy fingers, soft as dream,       The boat was lured into the stream.
column305: Out from the wharf it slipped and swung--       On the old rope one moment hung--       Then snapped its tether and away       For the storm-beaten outer bay.
column306: In Whitewaters, in Whitewaters,       No watcher heeds, no rescuer stirs.
column307: Out from the port the currents sweep       With Hally, smiling in his sleep.
column308: An hour they drifted, till the boat       From the low shore one scarce might note.
column309: The kitten climbed the prow, and mewed       Against the watery solitude.
column310: Then Hally woke, and stared with eyes       Grown round and dark with grieved surprise.
column312: And where       The gray old wharf, the weedy stair?
column313: Bewildered, and but half awake,       He sobbed as if his heart would break;       Then, as his lonely terror grew,       Down in the boat himself he threw,       And passionately for comfort pressed       The kind white kitten to his breast.
column314: Through the thin plank his hand could feel       The little eddies clutch the keel;       Lost and alone, lost and alone,       He heard the long wave hiss and moan,       He heard the wild ebb seethe and mourn       Along the outer shoals forlorn.
column315: And now a wind that chafed the flood       Blew down from Noel’s haunted wood;       And now in the dread tides that run       Past the grim front of Blomidon,       Over the rolling troughs, between       The purple gulfs, the slopes of green,       With sickening glide and sullen rest       The old boat climbed from crest to crest.
column316: *       *       *       *       *       That day in his good ship, “The Foam,”       Shipmaster Clive was speeding home;       His heart was light, his eyes elate;       His voyage had been fortunate.
column317: “If the wind holds,” said he, “to-night       We’ll anchor under Kingsport Light;--       I’ll change the fogs of Fundy wild       For Whitewaters and wife and child.”       He marked the drifting boat, and laughed,       “What clumsy lubber’s lost his craft?”       “What’s that that walks the gunwale?” cried       A sailor leaning o’er the side.
column321: We’ll give it passage in ‘The Foam’”--       Soft is the heart that’s bound for home!
column322: “Stop for a kitten?” growled the mate:--       “Look to the sun; we’re getting late!
column323: If we lose this tack we’ll lie to-night       A long ways off o’ Kingsport Light.”       The Captain paused irresolute;--       “To leave the helpless little brute       To the wrecked seaman’s death accurst,       The slow fierce hunger, the mad thirst,--       “I wish not my worst enemy       Such death as that!
column325: The ship came up into the wind;       The slackening canvas flapped and dinned;       And the ship’s boat with scant delay       Was swung and lowered and away,--       The Captain at the helm, and four       Stout men of Avon at the oar.
column326: They neared the drifting craft; and when       They bumped against her gunwale, then       Hally upraised his tumbled head!
column329: *       *       *       *       *       And now with bellying sails “The Foam”       Up the tossed flood went straining home;       The wind blew fair; she lay that night       At anchor under Kingsport Light.
column330: And late that night, in gladness deep       Sank father, mother, child, to sleep,--       Where no storm breaks, nor terror stirs       The peace of God in Whitewaters.
column331: The Forest Fire       The night was grim and still with dread;         No star shone down from heaven’s dome;       The ancient forest closed around         The settler’s lonely home.
column332: There came a glare that lit the north;         There came a wind that roused the night;       But child and father slumbered on,         Nor felt the growing light.
column333: There came a noise of flying feet,         With many a strange and dreadful cry;       And sharp flames crept and leapt along         The red verge of the sky.
column334: There came a deep and gathering roar.
column335: The father raised his anxious head;       He saw the light, like a dawn of blood,         That streamed across his bed.
column336: It lit the old clock on the wall,         It lit the room with splendor wild,       It lit the fair and tumbled hair         Of the still sleeping child;       And zigzag fence, and rude log barn,         And chip-strewn yard, and cabin gray,       Glowed crimson in the shuddering glare         Of that untimely day.
column337: The boy was hurried from his sleep;         The horse was hurried from his stall;       Up from the pasture clearing came         The cattle’s frightened call.
column338: The boy was snatched to the saddle-bow.
column340: Behind them swooped the hordes of flame         And harried their abode.
column341: The scorching heat was at their heels;         The huge roar hounded them in their flight;       Red smoke and many a flying brand         Flew o’er them through the night.
column342: And past them fled the wildwood forms--         Far-striding moose, and leaping deer,       And bounding panther, and coursing wolf,         Terrible-eyed with fear.
column343: And closer drew the fiery death;         Madly, madly, the father rode;       The horse began to heave and fail         Beneath the double load.
column344: The father’s mouth was white and stern,         But his eyes grew tender with long farewell.
column345: He said: “Hold fast to your seat, Sweetheart,         And ride Old Jerry well!
column348: Over the ford and the long marsh ride,       Straight on to the town.
column349: And I’ll meet you, Sweetheart,         Somewhere on the other side.”       He slipped from the saddle.
column351: His hand clung fast in the horse’s mane;       His hair blew over the horse’s neck;         His small throat sobbed with pain.
column354: The howl of the fire-wind answered him       With the hiss of soaring flames, and crash         Of shattering limb on limb.
column355: But still the good horse galloped on,         With sinew braced and strength renewed.
column356: The boy came safe to the river ford,         And out of the deadly wood.
column357: *       *       *       *       *       And now with his kinsfolk, fenced from fear,         At play in the heart of the city’s hum,       He stops in his play to wonder why         His father does not come!
column358: The Vengeance of Gluskâp                 _A Micmac Legend_       Gluskâp, the friend and father of his race,       With help in need went journeying three days’ space.
column359: His village slept, and took no thought of harm,       Secure beneath the shadow of his arm.
column360: But wandering wizards watched his outward path,       And marked his fenceless dwelling for their wrath.
column361: They came upon the tempest’s midnight wings,       With shock of thunder and the lightning’s slings,       And flame, and hail, and all disastrous things.
column362: When home at length the hero turned again,       His huts were ashes and his servants slain;       And o’er the ruin wept a slow, great rain.
column363: He wept not; but he cried a mighty word       Across the wandering sea, and the sea heard.
column364: Then came great whales, obedient to his hand,       And bare him to the demon-haunted land,       Where, in malign morass and ghostly wood       And grim cliff-cavern, lurked the evil brood.
column365: And scarce the avenger’s foot had touched their coast       Ere horror seized on all the wizard host,       And in their hiding-places hushed the boast.
column366: He grew and gloomed before them like a cloud,       And his eye drew them till they cried aloud,       And withering like spent flame before his frown       They ran forth in a madness and fell down.
column367: Rank upon rank they lay without a moan,--       His finger touched them, and their hearts grew stone.
column368: All round the coasts he heaped their stiffened clay;       And the seamews wail o’er them to this day.
column369: The Muse and the Wheel       The poet took his wheel one day         A-wandering to go,       But soon fell out beside the way,         The leaves allured him so.
column370: He leaned his wheel against a tree         And in the shade lay down;       And more to him were bloom and bee         Than all the busy town.
column371: He listened to the Phœbe-bird         And learned a thing worth knowing.
column372: He lay so still he almost heard         The merry grasses growing.
column373: He lay so still he dropped asleep;         And then the Muse came by.
